[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: RegisterTokenInfo()] [Symbol Case Sensitivity Race] Line 233 sets State.InsensitiveTokenExisting[symbol.ToUpper()] = true AFTER State.TokenInfos[symbol] is set. Can two threads register 'TOKEN' and 'token' simultaneously, both passing ToUpper check? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: RegisterTokenInfo()] [Total Supply Validation] Line 229 checks totalSupply > 0, but not checking against maximum safe value. Can attacker set totalSupply to Int64.MaxValue causing overflow in future operations? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: RegisterTokenInfo()] [Issuer/Owner Validation] Lines 230-231 check Issuer and Owner are not null, but do they verify these addresses exist or are valid contracts? Can attacker set burned/inaccessible address as owner/issuer? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: RegisterTokenInfo()] [TokenName Validation] Line 228 checks TokenName is not empty, but not checking length or content. Can attacker set extremely long name or inject special characters causing storage/display issues? (Low)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: RegisterTokenInfo()] [Symbol Validation Order] IsValidSymbol is called line 226 but InsensitiveTokenExisting is set line 233. Can attacker exploit timing between validation and state update to register duplicate symbols? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: GetCrossChainTokenContractRegistrationController()] [State Mismatch] Line 258 sets State.ParliamentContract.Value but line 260 calls Context.Call on parliamentContractAddress (not State value). Which takes precedence and can attacker exploit this discrepancy? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: GetCrossChainTokenContractRegistrationController()] [Default Organization Takeover] Line 260 gets DefaultOrganizationAddress. If Parliament contract is compromised or replaced, can attacker gain controller access by manipulating default organization? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: GetCrossChainTokenContractRegistrationController()] [Authority Info Tampering] AuthorityInfo is constructed in-memory (lines 256-263). Can attacker call this function repeatedly to cause different results based on state changes, bypassing authority checks? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: GetIssueChainId()] [Chain ID Manipulation] GetTokenInfo returns tokenInfo with IssueChainId. Can attacker create token with IssueChainId = 0 or negative value to bypass chain validation checks? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: AssertValidCreateInput()] [Decimals Overflow] Line 276 checks decimals <= MaxDecimals, but not checking for negative decimals despite line 276 having decimals >= 0. Is negative decimals check redundant or missing? (Low)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: AssertValidCreateInput()] [Symbol Length Race] CheckSymbolLength is called line 279 but symbol can be NFT with separator. Does CheckSymbolLength properly handle 'TOKEN-1234...' format or only check prefix? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: AssertValidCreateInput()] [TokenName Length] Line 274 checks TokenName.Length <= TokenNameLength, but what if TokenName contains multi-byte UTF-8 characters? Does Length count bytes or characters, allowing oversized names? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: AssertValidCreateInput()] [Whitelist Conditional] Line 282 only calls CheckSymbolSeed if IsAddressInCreateWhiteList returns true. Can non-whitelisted attacker bypass seed validation to create controlled symbol names? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: AssertValidCreateInput()] [SymbolType Bypass] If symbolType is Nft, line 280 returns early skipping CheckTokenAndCollectionExists. Can attacker create malformed NFT that bypasses collection validation? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: CheckTokenAndCollectionExists()] [Split Vulnerability] Line 287 splits by NFTSymbolSeparator. Can attacker include separator in symbol prefix to manipulate split results and bypass token existence checks? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: CheckTokenAndCollectionExists()] [Collection Symbol Hardcoded] Lines 290-291 construct collectionSymbol with fixed '0' suffix. Can attacker register token ending in '-0' to collide with collection symbols? (Critical)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: CheckTokenExists()] [Empty TokenInfo Equals] Line 300 checks 'existing.Equals(empty)'. Does Equals properly compare all fields or can attacker create token with partial initialization that passes as 'empty'? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: CheckTokenExists()] [Double Check Race] Lines 299-302 check both old token (State.TokenInfos) and new token (State.InsensitiveTokenExisting). Can transaction pass first check but fail second in race condition, leaving inconsistent state? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: CheckSymbolLength()] [SymbolType Confusion] Lines 307-310 have different max lengths for Token vs NFT. Can attacker create symbol that's valid for one type but passes as another type, bypassing length restrictions? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: CheckCrossChainTokenContractRegistrationControllerAuthority()] [Lazy Initialization Race] Lines 315-317 initialize controller if null. Can two transactions both see null state and both call GetCrossChainTokenContractRegistrationController, creating race condition? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: CheckCrossChainTokenContractRegistrationControllerAuthority()] [Owner Address Validation] Line 318 checks OwnerAddress == Context.Sender, but does not validate if OwnerAddress is valid/non-zero. Can uninitialized owner cause everyone to fail check or attacker to pass? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: CheckCrossChainTokenContractRegistrationControllerAuthority()] [State Persistence] After setting State.CrossChainTokenContractRegistrationController.Value (line 316), can attacker reset it by calling with crafted input, bypassing authority on subsequent calls? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: DealWithExternalInfoDuringLocking()] [Reentrancy via Callback] Line 331 calls Context.SendInline to external contract. Can malicious contract reenter TokenContract during lock operation, manipulating balances before lock completes? (Critical)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: DealWithExternalInfoDuringLocking()] [JSON Parsing DoS] Line 329 parses JSON from ExternalInfo. Can attacker craft malformed JSON or deeply nested structure causing parser to hang or crash? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Helper.cs] [Function: DealWithExternalInfoDuringLocking()] [ExternalInfo Key Control] Line 326 checks for LockCallbackExternalInfoKey. Can attacker who controls token creation set arbitrary callback address to steal locked tokens via malicious callback? (Critical)
